body: I talked with @jdfreder and have been using this for talks. Right now this uses the currently selected cell to determine what the "next" and "prev" slide should be. We decided that it should use the scroll position instead. He is going to implement that and I will then test more.

Talked more with @jdfreder. Seems like there are three possible scrolling behaviors users might want:
- Traditional page up/down behavior.
- Based on a particular heading level (default to h1).
- Based on slide metadata.

To enable everyone to play with these different options, he is going to implement these behaviors as three different `ScrollManager` subclasses and offer a drop down in the toolbar for selecting which is active (default to page up/down). Not sure if this is the final UI we will want, but this will make it easy for everyone to test the different options.

> Thanks! I will have a look.

I've assigned Brian.

From the dev meeting: make the slideshow mode the default, and there's no need to implement GUI options for this - if people want to modify this behaviour, they can use custom.js.

Also, I personally think we should consider making the slideshow mode 'jump towards the next slide by at most 1 page', rather than the current 'jump to the next slide, or one page if after the last slide'. With the current behaviour, if you accidentally add slide metadata to one cell, it prevents space-scrolling through the content above it. On the other hand, as @ivanov pointed out, you may want to have setup code at the start of a presentation that you can easily skip over.
Dev meeting comments addressed and rebased @ellisonbg .
Hey @ellisonbg how has this been working for you in your tour across America?

Rebase failure fixed

From the comments, it sounds like the default behavior of using slides for scroll markers instead of heading cells was discussed, but I'm quite surprised by the result. It seems illogical that the scroll manager isn't functional by default without custom metadata, whereas using heading cells would work without any rarely-used metadata. But if this has been discussed already, I won't rehash it.  :+1: if people consider that discussion settled.

I am honestly close to 50/50 on what the default should be (slide or
heading). IIRC, both @ivanov and @takluyver were in favor of the slides as
default.

I met with a few of the Julia folks on Friday and they asked about slide show stuff. They liked the idea of this PR, but thought, hands down, that the default scroll manager should be heading==1. After thinking more, I probably agree with that. Any objections to that? @fperez @minrk @jdfreder @ivanov @takluyver @Carreau ?
I've been leaning on that direction too, so +1 to using H1
The most logical default to me seems like heading==7 (i.e. _any_ heading) rather than only the coarsest level.

@minrk, I may be misunderstanding how the mechanism actually works (I haven't tested the PR), but it would seem to me that you still may want to have other heading levels that don't trigger a slide transition. No?

The current heading scroller matches the heading number exactly

Sent from my iPhone

> On Aug 23, 2014, at 6:44 PM, Fernando Perez notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> @minrk, I may be misunderstanding how the mechanism actually works (I haven't tested the PR), but it would seem to me that you still may want to have other heading levels that don't trigger a slide transition. No?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

> The current heading scroller matches the heading number exactly

That seems like a bug. Shouldn't it match `heading.level >= SM.heading_level`? Exact match only makes sense to me for level == 1.

> it would seem to me that you still may want to have other heading levels that don't trigger a slide transition.

If you want to associate the scroll behavior with slide transitions, you would want to use the Slide mode. If you want to associate it with heading cells, you would use the heading behavior. Both are supported, we are just discussing which one is the most sensible default.

Under normal circumstances, every heading that I create is a place to jump to, so I don't normally have any headings that I would want this code to skip over. That means that level == 7 makes the most sense for me, personally, but a logical middle ground for the default would be h3/4, if people think using every heading is crazy. I do think only using h1 is unnecessarily extreme in the opposite direction.

@minrk, thanks for the explanation. I was thinking of this for slide-style presentations, b/c @ellisonbg described being very happy using it in that manner. That's why I was thinking H1-only would make sense.  But the use case you're describing is different, and makes sense.

Perhaps I misunderstood Brian's description? If so, I don't want to add noise and confuse the discussion...

`h1` only seem a bit harsh, but `hx, x>1` can be annoying at the beginning of section where you have a `h(y+1)` just after a `hy` for `x>y+1` and will actually only scroll 1 cell at a time. So I'm fine with both.

The last two commits change the behavior of the HeadingScrollManager to scroll to `level <= target` and make the HeadingScrollManager the default scroll manager instead of the SlideScrollManager.  I left the default target heading level set to 1.   Anything else you guys want me to do before this is merged?

I am -1 on this change - will try to post details later - functioning with extreme exhaustion right now...
